Issues.Title: Fixing ToolStripMenu  checked box rendering issue when Visual Styles are ON
Issues.Body:
#fixes 1597. This was a regression when we change from StringBuilder to span<char> for optimization.

We allocate fixed size char that was a 'null terminated'
and span.ToString() method was not trimming those null terminated chars.
This was causign all comparision on the string that were converted
from span<char> to fail.

Fixes #1597 


## Proposed changes

Trimming the string for 'null terminated' chars before returning.

## Customer Impact

Checked boxes rendering on menu strip, in customer application, behave differently  when Visual Styles or ON/OFF.
## Regression? 
- Yes 

## Risk

- Low

## Screenshots <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->

### Before

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/36968667/64217966-7b335280-ce74-11e9-8855-acc4788dbc82.png)


### After
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/36968667/64217960-6eaefa00-ce74-11e9-8c8d-6a09d610f586.png)


## Test methodology <!-- How did you ensure quality? -->

- manual validation of the scenario


###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](http://wpcp.azurewebsites.net/CodeFlowProtocolProxy2.php?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/1751)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Fixing ToolStripMenu  checked box rendering issue when Visual Styles are ON" (#1751)

Issues.Title: Use Dictionary in NativeWindow
Issues.Body:
## Proposed changes

- Break NativeWindow subclass into separate file
- Fix naming
- Remove custom hashset

Following what is going on in NativeWindow is more confusing than it needs to be with the custom hashset implementation. Switching to Dictionary, which didn't exist when this code was originally written.

I have three commits to make this easier to follow. Note that I've other changes that build on this, moving more into Interop and using a WindowMessage enum as we do in the designer. (These will be follow up PR's in the future.)

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](http://wpcp.azurewebsites.net/CodeFlowProtocolProxy2.php?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/1748)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Use Dictionary in NativeWindow" (#1748)

Issues.Title: Fix issue 1746 - Screen reader is not announcing change in expanded/collapsed state of PropertyGrid Category item
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please read CONTRIBUTING.md before submitting a pull request -->

Fixes #1746


## Proposed changes

- Adding triggering ScreenReader announcement by raising UIA property changed event for ExpandedCollapsed automation property.
- Changed accessibility control type of Category items to TreeItem to allow announcement (as DataItem control type does not support ExpandCollapse property announcement: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/winauto/uiauto-controlpatternmapping 

<!-- We are in TELL-MODE the following section must be completed -->

## Customer Impact

- Screen reader users will get to know that if PropertyGrid Category item is expanded or collapsed.

## Regression? 

- No

## Risk

- Minimal

<!-- end TELL-MODE -->


## Screenshots <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->

### Before

![PropertyGrid_Category_Expand_collapse](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23213980/64197949-f3f3d800-ce8f-11e9-9ca5-f56d4be5dd6d.gif)


### After

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23213980/64194607-416c4700-ce88-11e9-8a6c-25153e0b5202.png)



## Test methodology <!-- How did you ensure quality? -->

- Manual testing. Verified using Screen Reader apps.
- Unit tests to be implemented.
- QA: needs to be verified.

## Accessibility testing  <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->

<!--
     Microsoft prioritizes making our products accessible. 
     WinForms has a key role in allowing developers to create accessible apps. 
     
     When submitting a change which impacts UI in any way, including adding new UI or
     modifying existing controls the developer needs to run the Accessibility Insights
     tool (https://accessibilityinsights.io/) and verify that there are no changes or
     regressions. 
     
     The developer should run the Fast Pass over the impacted control(s) and provide
     a snapshot of the passing results along with before/after snapshots of the UI.
     More info: (https://accessibilityinsights.io/docs/en/web/getstarted/fastpass)
  -->


 

## Test environment(s) <!-- Remove any that don't apply -->

Issues.Title: Screen reader is not announcing change in expanded/collapsed state of PropertyGrid Category item
Issues.Body:
*Repro steps:*
1. Create and launch .NET Core WinForms application project with PropertyGrid control with properties bound to some object/control.
2. Start Screenreader.
3. Navigate till any Category and hit enter to change its expanded/collapsed state.
 
*Actual:*
When navigated to any Category inside table for example, Accessibility & it is in expanded state then Narrator will announce it as expanded, but if we hit enter to collapse it, narrator is not announcing its new state which is collapsed.
Note: this issue is common for both Narrator & NVDA.
 
*Expected:*
Screen reader should announce current state of Category accordion whether it is expanded or collapsed (changing state should trigger announcement).
 
*User Impact:*
Screen reader users will not get to know that if Category accordion is expanded or collapsed.

DevDiv issue: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/956737
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Screen reader is not announcing change in expanded/collapsed state of PropertyGrid Category item" (#1746)

Issues.Title: fix: RichTextBox `LinkClicked` event for "friendly named" hyperlinks
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please read CONTRIBUTING.md before submitting a pull request -->

Fixes #1631
Relates to #1139


## Proposed changes

The newer RichEdit controls (v4.1+) in specific cases had troubles detecting "friendly named" hyperlinks as the `Text` property was reportig less characters than the rage of the actual hyperlink.

<!-- We are in TELL-MODE the following section must be completed -->

## Customer Impact

- "friendly named" hyperlinks raise `LinkClicked` events in RichEdit v4.1+.

## Regression? 

- Yes

## Risk

- Low

Issues.Title: WinForms designer throws InvalidCastException on save
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 3.0.100-preview9-013709
* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: Yes

**Problem description:**

When I put a control on a form in the VS Windows Forms designer and try to save the file, I get a dialog saying "The specified cast is not valid". I cannot successfully save any form with a control on it, ever. Due to #147, this only applies to the .NET Framework version of Windows Forms, as the .NET Core version doesn't support the designer yet. However, I suspect that even if the .NET Core designer worked, I would still run into this problem.

**Actual behavior:**

I get a dialog saying "The specified cast is not valid" whenever I try to save a form that has a control on it.

**Expected behavior:**

I am able to save my changes!

**Minimal repro:**

1. Install VS 16.3.0 Preview 2.0. (This is the version I am currently using; though IIRC this problem also occurred on 16.2.1.)
2. `dotnet new winforms -o reprotest`; open reprotest.sln
3. Retarget to net45 (to enable Designer support)
4. Open Form1.cs in the Designer, place a button on the form.
5. Attempt to save the form, and observe the error dialog.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "WinForms designer throws InvalidCastException on save" (#1744)

Issues.Title: Standardise some User32 struct interop
Issues.Body:
## Proposed changes

- Use structs instead of classes
- Avoid allocating HGlobals and prefer pointers
- Consolidate common code

## Customer Impact

- Fewer allocations
- Code size reductions

## Regression? 

- No

## Risk

- Minimal

## Test methodology <!-- How did you ensure quality? -->

- Existing tests

Issues.Title: ListView headers are not keyboard-accessible
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: (e.g. 3.0 Preview1, or daily build number, use `dotnet --info`)
* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: Yes/No
.Net Framework 4.7.2
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/master/Documentation/issue-guide.md -->

**Problem description:**
The ListView control contains column headers that can be clicked in order to perform sort actions on its contents.  There is currently no way to navigate through those column headers using a keyboard, nor can they be activated using a keyboard.  


**Actual behavior:** 
Non-keyboard-accessible column headers in ListView objects

**Expected behavior:**
ListViews should support basic accessibility guidelines such as keyboard navigability.

**Minimal repro:**

[Form1.cs.txt](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/3557703/Form1.cs.txt)
[Form1.Designer.cs.txt](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/3557704/Form1.Designer.cs.txt)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "ListView headers are not keyboard-accessible" (#1726)

Issues.Title: fix `PowerStatus_BatteryChargeStatus_Get_ReturnsExpected` test
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please read CONTRIBUTING.md before submitting a pull request -->


## Proposed changes

PowerStatus_BatteryChargeStatus_Get_ReturnsExpected was not correctly validating combination of flags.
The test was likely written on a workstation permanently connected to a power point. As a result the test did not account for combination of flags that can occur on laptops that are not permanently connected, e.g. if a laptop was being charged querying power would result in a combination of flags, such as `HIGH | CHARGING`.

Enhance the test to assert on combinations of valid flags.

<!-- We are in TELL-MODE the following section must be completed -->

## Customer Impact

- None, test change only

## Regression? 

- No

## Risk

- None, test change only

<!-- end TELL-MODE -->


## Screenshots <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->

### Before

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4403806/63942763-04164c80-ca77-11e9-8a51-072432edb7a7.png)



## Test methodology <!-- How did you ensure quality? -->

- manually running on a laptop partially discarged plugged and unplugged.
